definitions.definition: to defeat somebody in a game or competition

examples.text: He beat me at chess.
She was **narrowly beaten** by the German in the final.
I beat her by just three points.
Their recent wins have proved they're still **the ones to beat** *(= the most difficult team to beat)*.
He was beaten into second place by the American.
He was narrowly beaten by his opponent.
Watson was a higher-rated player who consistently beat her.
Her entry really did beat the others hands down.
She won the 100 metres, beating a number of top Europeans.
They were soundly beaten in the finals by a much stronger Dutch side.

phrases: beat somebody into second, third, etc. place

definitions.definition: to do or be better than something

examples.text: **Nothing beats** home cooking.
**You can't beat** Italian shoes.
For a break in the sun, Thailand is **hard to beat**.
They want to **beat the** speed **record** *(= go faster than anyone before)*.
This is his latest attempt to beat the world record.

definitions.definition: to get control of something

examples.text: The government's main aim is to beat inflation.
Book a break in the sun to try to beat those winter blues.
He is struggling to beat his addiction.
The new law is a way of trying to beat terrorism.

definitions.definition: to be too difficult for somebody
definitions.sensetop: beat somebodybeat somebody why, how, etc…

examples.text: It is a problem that beats even the experts.
**It beats me** *(= I don't know)* why he did it.
**What beats me** *(= what I don't understand)* is how it was done so quickly.
‘Where's she gone?’ ‘Beats me.’

definitions.definition: to avoid something

examples.text: If we go early we should beat the traffic.
We were up and off early to **beat the heat**.

definitions.definition: to hit a person hard and many times in order to hurt them
definitions.sensetop: beat somebodybeat somebody + adv./prep.beat somebody + adj.

examples.text: At that time children were regularly beaten for quite minor offences *(= as a punishment)*.
A man was found **beaten to death**.
The prisoners were beaten into submission *(= they were beaten until they did what was wanted)*.
They beat him unconscious *(= hit him until he became unconscious)*.
The men took him out into the street and **beat him senseless**.
His stepfather repeatedly beat his mother.
He had been beaten around the head with a rock.
They used to get beaten with a wooden spoon.

definitions.definition: to hit something hard several times

examples.text: Somebody was beating at the door.
Hailstones beat against the window.
Someone was **beating a drum**.
I was beating dust out of the rugs *(= removing dust from the rugs by beating them)*.
They could hear the rain beating on the roof.
He was beating the carpet with a large brush.

definitions.definition: to make, or cause something to make, a regular sound or movement

examples.text: She's alive—her **heart is** still **beating**.
His heart started beating faster.
We heard the **drums beating**.
The bird was **beating its wings** *(= moving them up and down)* frantically.
Her heart began to beat a little faster.
I could feel my heart beating wildly.
I could detect a pulse beating very faintly.
Its wings beat feebly against the window.

definitions.definition: to mix something with short quick movements with a fork, etc.
definitions.sensetop: beat something upbeat somethingbeat A and B together

examples.text: Beat the eggs up to a frothy consistency.
Beat the mixture well, until it is light and creamy.
Add three eggs, lightly beaten.
Beat the flour and milk together.

definitions.definition: to change the shape of something, especially metal, by hitting it with a hammer, etc.

examples.text: The gold is beaten out into thin strips.
beaten silver
The metal had been beaten flat.

definitions.definition: to make a path, etc. by walking somewhere or by pressing branches down and walking over them
definitions.sensetop: beat something (through, across, along, etc. something)

examples.text: a well-beaten track *(= one that has been worn hard by much use)*
The hunters beat a path through the undergrowth.

definitions.definition: to talk about something for a long time without coming to the main point

examples.text: Stop beating about the bush and tell me what you want.

definitions.definition: to defeat or do better than somebody in an activity which they have chosen or in which they think they are strong
to think very hard about something for a long time

examples.text: I’ve been beating my brains out all weekend to get this script written.

definitions.definition: to show that you feel sorry about something that you have done, especially in public and in an exaggerated way
to finish a task, race, etc. before a particular time

examples.text: The player beat the clock and set a new record.

definitions.definition: to hit somebody very hard several times and hurt them very much

examples.text: Get out or I’ll beat the living daylights out of you!

definitions.definition: to waste your effort by trying to do something that is no longer possible
to speak with enthusiasm in support of somebody/something

examples.text: She’s really banging the drum for the new system.

definitions.definition: to hit somebody/something very hard

examples.text: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

definitions.definition: to go away immediately

examples.text: This is private land, so beat it!

definitions.definition: if a lot of people beat a path to somebody’s door, they are all interested in something that person has to sell, or can do or tell them

examples.text: Top theatrical agents are beating a path to the teenager's door.

definitions.definition: to escape without being punished
to go away or back quickly, especially to avoid something unpleasant

examples.text: I decided to beat a hasty retreat.

definitions.definition: to mark or follow the rhythm of music, by waving a stick, tapping your foot (= hitting it against the floor), etc.

examples.text: She beat time with her fingers.

definitions.definition: to get or do something before somebody else can
(to hit somebody until they are) covered with bruises (= blue, brown or purple marks on the body)
used to express surprise or anger
if you cannot defeat somebody or be as successful as they are, then it is more sensible to join them in what they are doing and perhaps get some advantage for yourself by doing so
far away from other people, houses, etc.

examples.text: They live miles off the beaten track.

definitions.definition: a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody
to be difficult to beat

examples.text: That score is going to take some beating.
For sheer luxury, this hotel takes some beating.

wordOrigin: Old English bēatan, of Germanic origin.
